mn130:1.1.comm: Framed with the parable of the “messengers of the gods”, which are portents of mortality, this discourse expands the description of the power of clairvoyance or “divine eye” (dibbacakkhu), with a special emphasis on the descriptions of the torments of hell (niraya). This was a very popular discourse, with no fewer than six Chinese parallels and multiple references in Sanskrit literature. The Sinhala chronicle says it was taught as a primary text in Mahisamaṇḍala by Mahādeva, and in Sri Lanka by Mahinda, each time resulting in mass conversions (Mahāvaṁsa 12:29, 14:63).

mn130:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn130:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn130:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn130:2.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dve agārā sadvārā, tattha cakkhumā puriso majjhe ṭhito passeyya manusse gehaṃ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi anucaṅkamantepi anuvicarantepi;
mn130:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.

mn130:2.2.pli: evameva kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussesu upapannā. Ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā’ti.
mn130:2.2.eng: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or among humans. These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the ghost realm, the animal realm, or in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’

mn130:3.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā nānābāhāsu gahetvā yamassa rañño dassenti:
mn130:3.1.eng: The wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying,
mn130:3.1.comm: There is a set of beliefs about hell that is common to Buddhists, Hindus, and Jains. This “hell complex” includes such beliefs as: hell is long-lasting but impermanent; there are many named hells; punishments are terrible and varied; the punishment is determined by kamma; and tortures are inflicted by hell wardens. This sutta appears to be the earliest full account of this hell complex in Indian literature. Below I briefly outline the development of the hell complex in Brahmanical literature (MN 130:10.1).

mn130:3.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ, deva, puriso amatteyyo apetteyyo asāmañño abrāhmañño, na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyī.
mn130:3.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.

mn130:3.4.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
mn130:3.4.eng: King Yama pursues, presses, and grills them about the first messenger of the gods.

mn130:3.5.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
mn130:3.5.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
mn130:3.5.comm: Such “messengers of the gods” appear as reminders for the dangers of mortality. Five appear here—birth, old age, sickness, punishment, and death—while AN 3.36 has three, namely old age, sickness, and death. At MN 83:4.6 we meet just one, the grey hairs of old age. In non-Buddhist texts, such messengers can also be celestial interlocutors in a more literal sense (eg. Mahābhārata 1.2.232b, 1.9.005d). | Compare the four signs that prompted Vipassī’s going forth (DN 14:2.1.1).

mn130:4.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu daharaṃ kumāraṃ mandaṃ uttānaseyyakaṃ sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānan’ti?
mn130:4.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a little baby collapsed in their own urine and feces?’

mn130:4.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
mn130:4.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

mn130:4.7.pli: ahampi khomhi jātidhammo, jātiṃ anatīto. Handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
mn130:4.7.eng: “I, too, am liable to be born. I’m not exempt from rebirth. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

mn130:4.11.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādavatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
mn130:4.11.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn130:4.12.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
mn130:4.12.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

mn130:4.13.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ na pitarā kataṃ na bhātarā kataṃ na bhaginiyā kataṃ na mittāmaccehi kataṃ na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ na devatāhi kataṃ, tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
mn130:4.13.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

mn130:5.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
mn130:5.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the second messenger of the gods.

mn130:5.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
mn130:5.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the second messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

mn130:5.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā (…) jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyanaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantaṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ khaṇḍadantaṃ palitakesaṃ vilūnaṃ khalitasiraṃ valinaṃ tilakāhatagattan’ti?
mn130:5.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings an elderly woman or a man—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy?’

mn130:5.10.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
mn130:5.10.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

mn130:5.11.pli: ahampi khomhi jarādhammo, jaraṃ anatīto. Handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
mn130:5.11.eng: “I, too, am liable to grow old. I’m not exempt from old age. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

mn130:5.15.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādavatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
mn130:5.15.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn130:5.16.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
mn130:5.16.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

mn130:5.17.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ na pitarā kataṃ na bhātarā kataṃ na bhaginiyā kataṃ na mittāmaccehi kataṃ na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ na devatāhi kataṃ, tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
mn130:5.17.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

mn130:6.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
mn130:6.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the third messenger of the gods.

mn130:6.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
mn130:6.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the third messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

mn130:6.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ābādhikaṃ dukkhitaṃ bāḷhagilānaṃ sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānaṃ aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṃ aññehi saṃvesiyamānan’ti?
mn130:6.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others?’

mn130:6.10.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
mn130:6.10.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

mn130:6.11.eng: “I, too, am liable to become sick. I’m not exempt from sickness. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

mn130:6.12.pli: Handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti? So evamāha:

mn130:6.15.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādavatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
mn130:6.15.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn130:6.16.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
mn130:6.16.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

mn130:6.17.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ na pitarā kataṃ na bhātarā kataṃ na bhaginiyā kataṃ na mittāmaccehi kataṃ na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ na devatāhi kataṃ, tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
mn130:6.17.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

mn130:7.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā catutthaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
mn130:7.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the fourth messenger of the gods.

mn130:7.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu catutthaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
mn130:7.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the fourth messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

mn130:7.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu rājāno coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārente—
mn130:7.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings when the rulers arrested a bandit, a criminal, and subjected them to various punishments—

mn130:7.7.pli: kasāhipi tāḷente vettehipi tāḷente addhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷente hatthampi chindante pādampi chindante hatthapādampi chindante kaṇṇampi chindante nāsampi chindante kaṇṇanāsampi chindante bilaṅgathālikampi karonte saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonte rāhumukhampi karonte jotimālikampi karonte hatthapajjotikampi karonte erakavattikampi karonte cīrakavāsikampi karonte eṇeyyakampi karonte baḷisamaṃsikampi karonte kahāpaṇikampi karonte khārāpatacchikampi karonte palighaparivattikampi karonte palālapīṭhakampi karonte tattenapi telena osiñcante sunakhehipi khādāpente jīvantampi sūle uttāsente asināpi sīsaṃ chindante’ti?
mn130:7.7.eng: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘demon’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded?’

mn130:7.11.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
mn130:7.11.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

mn130:7.12.pli: ye kira, bho, pāpakāni kammāni karonti te diṭṭheva dhamme evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā karīyanti, kimaṅgaṃ pana parattha. Handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
mn130:7.12.eng: that if someone who does bad deeds receives such punishment in this very life, what must happen to them in the next; I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

mn130:7.16.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādavatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
mn130:7.16.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn130:7.17.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
mn130:7.17.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

mn130:7.18.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ na pitarā kataṃ na bhātarā kataṃ na bhaginiyā kataṃ na mittāmaccehi kataṃ na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ na devatāhi kataṃ, tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
mn130:7.18.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

mn130:8.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā catutthaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā pañcamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
mn130:8.1.eng: Then King Yama grills them about the fifth messenger of the gods.

mn130:8.2.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu pañcamaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
mn130:8.2.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the fifth messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’

mn130:8.6.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātan’ti?
mn130:8.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering?’

mn130:8.10.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
mn130:8.10.eng: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

mn130:8.11.pli: ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo, maraṇaṃ anatīto. Handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
mn130:8.11.eng: “I, too, am liable to die. I’m not exempt from death. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’

mn130:8.15.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādavatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
mn130:8.15.eng: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn130:8.16.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
mn130:8.16.eng: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

mn130:8.17.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ na pitarā kataṃ na bhātarā kataṃ na bhaginiyā kataṃ na mittāmaccehi kataṃ na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ na devatāhi kataṃ, tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti.
mn130:8.17.eng: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

mn130:9.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā pañcamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā tuṇhī hoti.
mn130:9.1.eng: After grilling them about the fifth messenger of the gods, King Yama falls silent.

mn130:10.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā pañcavidhabandhanaṃ nāma kammakāraṇaṃ karonti—
mn130:10.1.eng: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.
mn130:10.1.comm: The history of hell in India begins with the Rig Veda, which speaks of evil-doers facing the “erasure of the wolf”, the “downfall” (2.29.6c), the “bottomless darkness” (7.104.3) “beneath all three earths” (7.104.11), the “endless abyss” (7.104.17), the “darkness below” (10.152.4). Atharva Veda similarly speaks of the “house below” (2.14.3a), the “deepest dark” (8.2.24). It also consigns a man stingy with cattle to the nārakaṁ lokaṁ, which seems to mean “the world of the hell beings” (12.4.36c); there is an equally vague reference to a “hell being” at Śukla Yajur Veda 30.5. These seem to be the earliest uses of the word naraka in the sense of “hell”; this sense is not found in early Pali (see note on DN 12:78.2). Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42 describes the “other world” in both hellish and heavenly terms (see too Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.6.1). It depicts the hellish torments taking place in regions of the “other world” rather than as a distinct hell realm; and it does not share many details in common with later accounts. Thus far the texts are pre-Buddhist. It is not until the much later Purāṇic literature that lurid descriptions of hells, usually numbered 21 or 28, become a standard feature, along with the rest of the hell complex. Several of the places mentioned here correspond with the Purāṇic hells.

mn130:10.2.pli: tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ hatthe gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiye hatthe gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ pāde gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiye pāde gamenti, tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ majjheurasmiṃ gamenti.
mn130:10.2.eng: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.

mn130:10.3.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:10.3.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
mn130:10.3.comm: I give a few examples of similar descriptions in the Purāṇas and the Jain Sūtrakṛtāṅga, without any attempt to be comprehensive. | The notion that one does not die despite the suffering is also found at Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.28 and Sūtrakṛtāṅga 1.5.1.16. | The lifespan of one in hell is illustrated in the story of Kokālika (SN 6.10 = AN 10.89), which is repeated at Snp 3.10 with an expanded description of the hells that bears much in common with the present discourse.

mn130:11.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā saṃvesetvā kuṭhārīhi tacchanti …pe…
mn130:11.1.eng: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …

mn130:12.1.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā vāsīhi tacchanti …pe…
mn130:12.1.eng: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …
mn130:12.1.comm: Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.26; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23. There is a special “Upside-down hell” in Viṣṇu Purāṇa 2.63.

mn130:13.1.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā rathe yojetvā ādittāya pathaviyā sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya sārentipi, paccāsārentipi …pe…
mn130:13.1.eng: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …

mn130:14.1.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi …pe…
mn130:14.1.eng: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

mn130:15.1.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā tattāya lohakumbhiyā pakkhipanti ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya.
mn130:15.1.eng: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.

mn130:15.3.pli: So tattha pheṇuddehakaṃ paccamāno sakimpi uddhaṃ gacchati, sakimpi adho gacchati, sakimpi tiriyaṃ gacchati.
mn130:15.3.eng: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.

mn130:15.4.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:15.4.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:16.1.eng: The wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell.

mn130:16.3.eng: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,

mn130:16.7.eng: The ground is even made of iron,

mn130:16.8.comm: The Kālasūtra hell is made of burning copper (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.14).

mn130:17.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, mahānirayassa puratthimāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā pacchimāya bhittiyā paṭihaññati, pacchimāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā puratthimāya bhittiyā paṭihaññati, uttarāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā dakkhiṇāya bhittiyā paṭihaññati, dakkhiṇāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā uttarāya bhittiyā paṭihaññati, heṭṭhā acci uṭṭhahitvā upari paṭihaññati, uparito acci uṭṭhahitvā heṭṭhā paṭihaññati.
mn130:17.1.eng: Now in the Great Hell, flames surge out of the walls and crash into the opposite wall: from east to west, from west to east, from north to south, from south to north, from bottom to top, from top to bottom.

mn130:17.2.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:17.2.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:18.1.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena tassa mahānirayassa puratthimaṃ dvāraṃ apāpurīyati.
mn130:18.1.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the eastern gate of the Great Hell is opened.

mn130:18.2.eng: So they run there as fast as they can.
mn130:18.2.comm: Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.15 describes how the sinner runs about in pain trying to escape.

mn130:18.3.pli: Tassa sīghena javena dhāvato chavimpi ḍayhati, cammampi ḍayhati, maṃsampi ḍayhati, nhārumpi ḍayhati, aṭṭhīnipi sampadhūpāyanti, ubbhataṃ tādisameva hoti.
mn130:18.3.eng: And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. Such is their escape;

mn130:18.4.pli: Yato ca kho so, bhikkhave, bahusampatto hoti, atha taṃ dvāraṃ pidhīyati.
mn130:18.4.eng: but when they’ve managed to make it most of the way, the gate is slammed shut.

mn130:18.5.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:18.5.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:18.6.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the western gate …

mn130:18.8.eng: southern gate of the Great Hell is opened.

mn130:18.9.eng: So they run there as fast as they can.

mn130:18.10.eng: And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. Such is their escape;

mn130:18.11.pli: Yato ca kho so, bhikkhave, bahusampatto hoti, atha taṃ dvāraṃ pidhīyati.
mn130:18.11.eng: but when they’ve managed to make it most of the way, the gate is slammed shut.

mn130:18.12.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:18.12.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:19.1.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena tassa mahānirayassa puratthimaṃ dvāraṃ apāpurīyati.
mn130:19.1.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the eastern gate of the Great Hell is opened.

mn130:19.2.eng: So they run there as fast as they can.

mn130:19.3.pli: Tassa sīghena javena dhāvato chavimpi ḍayhati, cammampi ḍayhati, maṃsampi ḍayhati, nhārumpi ḍayhati, aṭṭhīnipi sampadhūpāyanti, ubbhataṃ tādisameva hoti.
mn130:19.3.eng: And as they run, their outer skin, inner skin, flesh, and sinews burn and even their bones smoke. Such is their escape;

mn130:19.4.eng: and they make it out that door.

mn130:20.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, mahānirayassa samanantarā sahitameva mahanto gūthanirayo.
mn130:20.1.eng: Immediately adjacent to the Great Hell is the vast Dung Hell.

mn130:20.3.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, gūthaniraye sūcimukhā pāṇā chaviṃ chindanti, chaviṃ chetvā cammaṃ chindanti, cammaṃ chetvā maṃsaṃ chindanti, maṃsaṃ chetvā nhāruṃ chindanti, nhāruṃ chetvā aṭṭhiṃ chindanti, aṭṭhiṃ chetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ khādanti.
mn130:20.3.eng: In that Dung Hell there are needle-mouthed creatures that bore through the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, sinews, and bones, until they reach the marrow and devour it.
mn130:20.3.comm: “Needle-mouth” (sūcimukha) is one of the 28 Purāṇic hells, the destiny of scrooges, where one is stitched as cloth by a tailor (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 526.36; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23). Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.42–3 describes how sinners are devoured by sharp-toothed worms while rotting in mounds of flesh; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.17 says one is devoured by the same creatures one killed while alive.

mn130:20.4.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:20.4.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:21.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, gūthanirayassa samanantarā sahitameva mahanto kukkulanirayo.
mn130:21.1.eng: Immediately adjacent to the Dung Hell is the vast Hell of Burning Chaff.
mn130:21.1.comm: Burning of remnant stubble is still a widespread practice in India, and it does indeed create hellish conditions.

mn130:21.3.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:21.3.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:22.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, kukkulanirayassa samanantarā sahitameva mahantaṃ simbalivanaṃ uddhaṃ yojanamuggataṃ soḷasaṅgulakaṇṭakaṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ.
mn130:22.1.eng: Immediately adjacent to the Hell of Burning Chaff is the vast Red Silk-Cotton Forest. It’s a league high, full of sixteen-inch thorns, burning, blazing, and glowing.
mn130:22.1.comm: The “Red Silk-Cotton Forest” (simbalivana) is one of the 28 hells (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.7; Devī Bhāgavatapurāṇa 10.21.11–28; Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.20). The red silk cotton tree (simbali, Sanskrit śālmalī, bombax ceiba) has a spiky trunk. Treading on the spikes could cause infections (Rig Veda 7.50.3). | This hell and the next reflect the miseries of struggling through thick, prickly jungles.

mn130:22.2.eng: And there they make them climb up and down.

mn130:22.3.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:22.3.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:23.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, simbalivanassa samanantarā sahitameva mahantaṃ asipattavanaṃ.
mn130:23.1.eng: Immediately adjacent to the Red Silk-Cotton Forest is the vast Sword-Leaf Forest.
mn130:23.1.comm: The “Sword-Leaf Forest” (asipattavana; also at Snp 3.10:25.1) is another of the 28 hells. This befalls those who destroy forests (Brahmāṇḍa Purāṇa 4.2.173; Viṣṇu Purāṇa 6.2), while Agni Purāṇa 203.10 says it is for one who killed their mother, and Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.15 says it is for one who strays from the Vedas.

mn130:23.3.pli: Tassa vāteritāni pattāni patitāni hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti.
mn130:23.3.eng: There the fallen leaves blown by the wind cut their hands, feet, both hands and feet; they cut their ears, nose, both ears and nose.

mn130:23.4.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:23.4.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:24.1.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhikkhave, asipattavanassa samanantarā sahitameva mahatī khārodakā nadī.
mn130:24.1.eng: Immediately adjacent to the Sword-Leaf Forest is the vast Acid River.
mn130:24.1.comm: The “Acid River” (khārodakā nadī) is yet another of the 28 hells (kṣārakardama, Śiva Purāṇa 5.9.8; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.30; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.21; Skanda Purāṇa 6.1.226.54).

mn130:24.3.pli: So tattha anusotampi vuyhati, paṭisotampi vuyhati, anusotapaṭisotampi vuyhati.
mn130:24.3.eng: There they are swept upstream, swept downstream, and swept both up and down stream.

mn130:24.4.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:24.4.eng: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:25.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā balisena uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpetvā evamāhaṃsu:
mn130:25.1.eng: The wardens of hell pull them out with a hook and place them on solid ground, and say,

mn130:25.5.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā tattena ayosaṅkunā mukhaṃ vivaritvā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena tattaṃ lohaguḷaṃ mukhe pakkhipanti ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ.
mn130:25.5.eng: The wardens of hell force open their mouth with a hot iron spike—burning, blazing, glowing—and shove in a red-hot copper ball, burning, blazing, and glowing.

mn130:25.6.pli: So tassa oṭṭhampi dahati, mukhampi dahati, kaṇṭhampi dahati, urampi dahati, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya adhobhāgā nikkhamati.
mn130:25.6.eng: It burns their lips, mouth, tongue, throat, and stomach before coming out below dragging their entrails.

mn130:25.7.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:25.7.eng: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:26.5.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā tattena ayosaṅkunā mukhaṃ vivaritvā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena tattaṃ tambalohaṃ mukhe āsiñcanti ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ.
mn130:26.5.eng: The wardens of hell force open their mouth with a hot iron spike—burning, blazing, glowing—and pour in molten copper, burning, blazing, and glowing.
mn130:26.5.comm: The “iron drink” (ayaḥpāna) is another Purāṇic hell (Agni Purāṇa 307.25–28; Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.29; Devī Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.23).

mn130:26.6.pli: Taṃ tassa oṭṭhampi dahati, mukhampi dahati, kaṇṭhampi dahati, urampi dahati, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya adhobhāgā nikkhamati.
mn130:26.6.eng: It burns their lips, mouth, tongue, throat, and stomach before coming out below dragging their entrails.

mn130:26.7.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti, yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
mn130:26.7.eng: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

mn130:27.1.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā puna mahāniraye pakkhipanti.
mn130:27.1.eng: The wardens of hell toss them back in the Great Hell.

mn130:28.1.eng: Once upon a time, King Yama thought:

mn130:28.2.pli: ‘ye kira, bho, loke pāpakāni akusalāni kammāni karonti te evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā karīyanti.
mn130:28.2.eng: ‘Those who do such bad deeds in the world receive these many different punishments.

mn130:28.3.pli: Aho vatāhaṃ manussattaṃ labheyyaṃ. Tathāgato ca loke uppajjeyya arahaṃ sammāsambuddho. Tañcāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāseyyaṃ.
mn130:28.3.eng: Oh, I hope I may be reborn as a human being! And that a Realized One—a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—arises in the world! And that I may pay homage to the Buddha!

mn130:28.4.pli: So ca me bhagavā dhammaṃ deseyya. Tassa cāhaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ ājāneyyan’ti.
mn130:28.4.eng: Then the Buddha can teach me Dhamma, so that I may understand his teaching.’

mn130:29.1.pli: Taṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nāññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā vadāmi, api ca yadeva sāmaṃ ñātaṃ sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sāmaṃ viditaṃ tadevāhaṃ vadāmī”ti.
mn130:29.1.eng: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.”
mn130:29.1.comm: This statement is found only in the Pali text, although Chinese texts are effectively similar, in that they all speak of the Buddha’s clairvoyance.

mn130:30.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn130:30.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
mn130:30.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

mn130:30.4.eng: those sons of Manu who are negligent

mn130:30.6.eng: when they go to that wretched place.

mn130:30.7.eng: When warned by the gods’ messengers,

mn130:30.8.eng: the good and true persons here

mn130:30.10.eng: the teaching of the Noble One.

mn130:30.12.eng: the origin of birth and death,

mn130:30.14.eng: with the ending of birth and death.

mn130:30.15.eng: Happy, they’ve come to a safe place,

mn130:30.17.eng: They’ve gone beyond all threats and perils,
